AI.conclusion: SANC(E3) provides a principled framework for emergent representation, unifying cognitive processes through energy minimization and selection, enabling more flexible and human-like generalization.

title: TabPFN Through The Looking Glass: An interpretability study of TabPFN and its internal representations
summary: Tabular foundational models are pre-trained models designed for a wide range of tabular data tasks. They have shown strong performance across domains, yet their internal representations and learned concepts remain poorly understood. This lack of interpretability makes it important to study how these models process and transform input features. In this work, we analyze the information encoded inside the model's hidden representations and examine how these representations evolve across layers. We run a set of probing experiments that test for the presence of linear regression coefficients, intermediate values from complex expressions, and the final answer in early layers. These experiments allow us to reason about the computations the model performs internally. Our results provide evidence that meaningful and structured information is stored inside the representations of tabular foundational models. We observe clear signals that correspond to both intermediate and final quantities involved in the model's prediction process. This gives insight into how the model refines its inputs and how the final output emerges. Our findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the internal mechanics of tabular foundational models. They show that these models encode concrete and interpretable information, which moves us closer to making their decision processes more transparent and trustworthy.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the internal representations and computational processes of tabular foundational models through probing experiments, revealing that they encode meaningful, structured information including linear regression coefficients, intermediate values, and final answers across layers.
AI.motivation: Tabular foundational models show strong performance but their internal representations and learned concepts remain poorly understood. This lack of interpretability makes it important to study how these models process and transform input features to make their decision processes more transparent and trustworthy.
AI.method: The researchers analyze information encoded in hidden representations and examine how representations evolve across layers. They conduct probing experiments testing for: 1) presence of linear regression coefficients, 2) intermediate values from complex expressions, and 3) final answers in early layers to reason about internal computations.
AI.result: Results provide evidence that meaningful and structured information is stored inside tabular foundational model representations. Clear signals correspond to both intermediate and final quantities involved in prediction processes, showing how the model refines inputs and how final outputs emerge.
AI.conclusion: The findings contribute to deeper understanding of internal mechanics of tabular foundational models, showing they encode concrete and interpretable information. This moves us closer to making their decision processes more transparent and trustworthy.

title: MPCI-Bench: A Benchmark for Multimodal Pairwise Contextual Integrity Evaluation of Language Model Agents
summary: As language-model agents evolve from passive chatbots into proactive assistants that handle personal data, evaluating their adherence to social norms becomes increasingly critical, often through the lens of Contextual Integrity (CI). However, existing CI benchmarks are largely text-centric and primarily emphasize negative refusal scenarios, overlooking multimodal privacy risks and the fundamental trade-off between privacy and utility. In this paper, we introduce MPCI-Bench, the first Multimodal Pairwise Contextual Integrity benchmark for evaluating privacy behavior in agentic settings. MPCI-Bench consists of paired positive and negative instances derived from the same visual source and instantiated across three tiers: normative Seed judgments, context-rich Story reasoning, and executable agent action Traces. Data quality is ensured through a Tri-Principle Iterative Refinement pipeline. Evaluations of state-of-the-art multimodal models reveal systematic failures to balance privacy and utility and a pronounced modality leakage gap, where sensitive visual information is leaked more frequently than textual information. We will open-source MPCI-Bench to facilitate future research on agentic CI.

AI.tldr: MPCI-Bench is the first multimodal benchmark for evaluating privacy behavior in AI agents using paired positive/negative instances across three tiers, revealing systematic failures in balancing privacy vs utility and a modality leakage gap.
AI.motivation: As language-model agents evolve into proactive assistants handling personal data, existing Contextual Integrity (CI) benchmarks are too text-centric and focus only on negative refusal scenarios, missing multimodal privacy risks and the privacy-utility trade-off fundamental to agentic systems.
AI.method: Introduced MPCI-Bench, a Multimodal Pairwise Contextual Integrity benchmark with paired positive/negative instances derived from same visual sources across three tiers: Seed normative judgments, context-rich Story reasoning, and executable agent action Traces. Used Tri-Principle Iterative Refinement pipeline to ensure data quality.
AI.result: Evaluations of state-of-the-art multimodal models show systematic failures in balancing privacy and utility, and a pronounced "modality leakage gap" where sensitive visual information is leaked more frequently than textual information.
AI.conclusion: MPCI-Bench addresses critical gaps in CI evaluation by incorporating multimodal scenarios and privacy-utility trade-offs. The benchmark will be open-sourced to facilitate future research on agentic Contextual Integrity.

title: Scalable Multiagent Reinforcement Learning with Collective Influence Estimation
summary:
Multiagent reinforcement learning (MARL) has attracted considerable attention due to its potential in addressing complex cooperative tasks. However, existing MARL approaches often rely on frequent exchanges of action or state information among agents to achieve effective coordination, which is difficult to satisfy in practical robotic systems. A common solution is to introduce estimator networks to model the behaviors of other agents and predict their actions; nevertheless, such designs cause the size and computational cost of the estimator networks to grow rapidly with the number of agents, thereby limiting scalability in large-scale systems.
  To address these challenges, this paper proposes a multiagent learning framework augmented with a Collective Influence Estimation Network (CIEN). By explicitly modeling the collective influence of other agents on the task object, each agent can infer critical interaction information solely from its local observations and the task object's states, enabling efficient collaboration without explicit action information exchange. The proposed framework effectively avoids network expansion as the team size increases; moreover, new agents can be incorporated without modifying the network structures of existing agents, demonstrating strong scalability. Experimental results on multiagent cooperative tasks based on the Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm show that the proposed method achieves stable and efficient coordination under communication-limited environments. Furthermore, policies trained with collective influence modeling are deployed on a real robotic platform, where experimental results indicate significantly improved robustness and deployment feasibility, along with reduced dependence on communication infrastructure.

AI.tldr: Proposes a scalable multiagent reinforcement learning framework using a Collective Influence Estimation Network (CIEN) to enable efficient coordination without explicit action exchanges, validated in communication-limited simulations and real robotic deployments.
AI.motivation: Existing MARL approaches often require frequent exchanges of action or state information among agents for coordination, which is impractical in real robotic systems due to communication constraints. Estimator networks used to predict other agents' actions suffer from scalability issues as their size and computational cost grow rapidly with the number of agents.
AI.method: The paper introduces a multiagent learning framework augmented with a Collective Influence Estimation Network (CIEN). Each agent models the collective influence of other agents on the task object using only local observations and the task object's states, eliminating the need for explicit action information exchange. The framework is built on the Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm and avoids network expansion as team size increases.
AI.result: Experimental results on multiagent cooperative tasks show that the proposed method achieves stable and efficient coordination under communication-limited environments. Policies trained with collective influence modeling demonstrate significantly improved robustness and deployment feasibility on a real robotic platform, with reduced dependence on communication infrastructure.
AI.conclusion: The proposed Collective Influence Estimation Network (CIEN) framework effectively addresses scalability and communication constraints in MARL by enabling agents to infer critical interaction information from local observations and task object states, thereby facilitating efficient collaboration without explicit action exchanges. It demonstrates strong scalability, robustness, and deployment feasibility in real robotic systems.

title: The End of Reward Engineering: How LLMs Are Redefining Multi-Agent Coordination
summary: Reward engineering, the manual specification of reward functions to induce desired agent behavior, remains a fundamental challenge in multi-agent reinforcement learning. This difficulty is amplified by credit assignment ambiguity, environmental non-stationarity, and the combinatorial growth of interaction complexity. We argue that recent advances in large language models (LLMs) point toward a shift from hand-crafted numerical rewards to language-based objective specifications. Prior work has shown that LLMs can synthesize reward functions directly from natural language descriptions (e.g., EUREKA) and adapt reward formulations online with minimal human intervention (e.g., CARD). In parallel, the emerging paradigm of Reinforcement Learning from Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) provides empirical evidence that language-mediated supervision can serve as a viable alternative to traditional reward engineering. We conceptualize this transition along three dimensions: semantic reward specification, dynamic reward adaptation, and improved alignment with human intent, while noting open challenges related to computational overhead, robustness to hallucination, and scalability to large multi-agent systems. We conclude by outlining a research direction in which coordination arises from shared semantic representations rather than explicitly engineered numerical signals.

AI.tldr: A shift in multi-agent reinforcement learning from manual reward engineering to language-based objectives using large language models, enabling semantic specification and dynamic adaptation of rewards while addressing alignment and scalability challenges.
AI.motivation: Manual reward engineering is difficult in multi-agent reinforcement learning due to credit assignment ambiguity, environmental non-stationarity, and combinatorial interaction complexity. This limits agent behavior induction and scalability.
AI.method: Leverage large language models to synthesize reward functions from natural language descriptions (e.g., EUREKA) and adapt rewards online with minimal human intervention (e.g., CARD), supported by the Reinforcement Learning from Verifiable Rewards framework.
AI.result: Language-based specifications enable semantic reward definition, dynamic adaptation, and improved alignment with human intent, though computational overhead, hallucination robustness, and scalability in large systems remain open issues.
AI.conclusion: Future research should focus on aligning multi-agent coordination through shared semantic representations rather than explicit numerical signals, transforming reward engineering toward more interpretable and scalable solutions.

title: One-Shot Federated Ridge Regression: Exact Recovery via Sufficient Statistic Aggregation
summary: Federated learning protocols require repeated synchronization between clients and a central server, with convergence rates depending on learning rates, data heterogeneity, and client sampling. This paper asks whether iterative communication is necessary for distributed linear regression. We show it is not. We formulate federated ridge regression as a distributed equilibrium problem where each client computes local sufficient statistics -- the Gram matrix and moment vector -- and transmits them once. The server reconstructs the global solution through a single matrix inversion. We prove exact recovery: under a coverage condition on client feature matrices, one-shot aggregation yields the centralized ridge solution, not an approximation. For heterogeneous distributions violating coverage, we derive non-asymptotic error bounds depending on spectral properties of the aggregated Gram matrix. Communication reduces from $\mathcal{O}(Rd)$ in iterative methods to $\mathcal{O}(d^2)$ total; for high-dimensional settings, we propose and experimentally validate random projection techniques reducing this to $\mathcal{O}(m^2)$ where $m \ll d$. We establish differential privacy guarantees where noise is injected once per client, eliminating the composition penalty that degrades privacy in multi-round protocols. We further address practical considerations including client dropout robustness, federated cross-validation for hyperparameter selection, and comparison with gradient-based alternatives. Comprehensive experiments on synthetic heterogeneous regression demonstrate that one-shot fusion matches FedAvg accuracy while requiring up to $38\times$ less communication. The framework applies to kernel methods and random feature models but not to general nonlinear architectures.

AI.tldr: One-shot federated ridge regression eliminates iterative communication by transmitting local statistics once, achieving exact solutions and up to 38x less communication with privacy benefits.
AI.motivation: Existing federated learning protocols require repeated synchronization between clients and a central server for distributed linear regression, introducing communication overhead and potential privacy risks due to multi-round interactions. The paper questions whether iterative communication is necessary and aims to develop a one-shot method that reduces communication and enhances privacy.
AI.method: The paper formulates federated ridge regression as a distributed equilibrium problem. Each client computes local sufficient statistics (Gram matrix and moment vector) and transmits them once to the server. The server reconstructs the global solution through a single matrix inversion. For high-dimensional settings, random projection techniques are proposed to reduce communication cost, typically from $\mathcal{O}(d^2)$ to $\mathcal{O}(m^2)$ where $m \ll d$. Practical considerations, such as client dropout robustness, federated cross-validation for hyperparameter selection, and differential privacy guarantees with noise injected once per client, are addressed.
AI.result: Under a coverage condition on client feature matrices, one-shot aggregation yields the exact centralized ridge solution, not an approximation. For heterogeneous distributions violating coverage, non-asymptotic error bounds are derived based on spectral properties of the aggregated Gram matrix. Communication is reduced from $\mathcal{O}(Rd)$ in iterative methods to $\mathcal{O}(d^2)$ total, with further reduction possible via random projections. Experiments on synthetic heterogeneous regression show that one-shot fusion matches FedAvg accuracy while requiring up to $38\times$ less communication.
AI.conclusion: Iterative communication is not necessary for distributed linear regression. The proposed one-shot federated ridge regression method achieves exact recovery under certain conditions, significantly reduces communication costs, and provides enhanced privacy through single-round noise injection. The framework applies to kernel methods and random feature models, though not to general nonlinear architectures.

title: Large Artificial Intelligence Model Guided Deep Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation in Non Terrestrial Networks
summary: Large AI Model (LAM) have been proposed to applications of Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN), that offer better performance with its great generalization and reduced task specific trainings. In this paper, we propose a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) agent that is guided by a Large Language Model (LLM). The LLM operates as a high level coordinator that generates textual guidance that shape the reward of the DRL agent during training. The results show that the LAM-DRL outperforms the traditional DRL by 40% in nominal weather scenarios and 64% in extreme weather scenarios compared to heuristics in terms of throughput, fairness, and outage probability.

AI.tldr: A Deep Reinforcement Learning agent guided by a Large Language Model for Non-Terrestrial Networks, where the LLM provides high-level textual guidance to shape the DRL agent's reward function during training.
AI.motivation: To leverage Large AI Models' generalization capabilities and reduce task-specific training requirements for Non-Terrestrial Networks applications, improving performance in challenging network scenarios.
AI.method: Proposes a LAM-DRL framework where a Large Language Model acts as a high-level coordinator, generating textual guidance that shapes the reward function of the Deep Reinforcement Learning agent during training.
AI.result: The LAM-DRL approach outperforms traditional DRL by 40% in nominal weather scenarios and 64% in extreme weather scenarios compared to heuristics, with improvements in throughput, fairness, and outage probability.
AI.conclusion: LLM-guided DRL represents a promising approach for NTN applications, demonstrating significant performance improvements over traditional methods, especially in challenging environmental conditions.

title: A Preliminary Agentic Framework for Matrix Deflation
summary: Can a small team of agents peel a matrix apart, one rank-1 slice at a time? We propose an agentic approach to matrix deflation in which a solver Large Language Model (LLM) generates rank-1 Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) updates and a Vision Language Model (VLM) accepts or rejects each update and decides when to stop, eliminating fixed norm thresholds. Solver stability is improved through in-context learning (ICL) and types of row/column permutations that expose visually coherent structure. We evaluate on Digits ($8{\times}8$), CIFAR-10 ($32{\times}32$ grayscale), and synthetic ($16{\times}16$) matrices with and without Gaussian noise. In the synthetic noisy case, where the true construction rank $k$ is known, numerical deflation provides the noise target and our best agentic configuration differs by only $1.75$ RMSE of the target. For Digits and CIFAR-10, targets are defined by deflating until the Frobenius norm reaches $10\%$ of the original. Across all settings, our agent achieves competitive results, suggesting that fully agentic, threshold-free deflation is a viable alternative to classical numerical algorithms.

AI.tldr: We propose an agentic approach to matrix deflation using an LLM and VLM to iteratively generate and validate rank-1 SVD updates without fixed thresholds, achieving competitive results on synthetic and real datasets.
AI.motivation: To enable small teams of agents to perform matrix deflation iteratively without relying on fixed norm thresholds, using AI models for decision-making rather than classical numerical methods.
AI.method: We use a solver LLM to generate rank-1 SVD updates, a VLM to accept/reject updates and decide stopping criteria, with techniques like in-context learning and row/column permutations to improve solver stability.
AI.result: Our agent achieves competitive results: in synthetic noisy cases, it differs by only 1.75 RMSE from the target; for Digits and CIFAR-10, it meets target deflation to 10% of the original Frobenius norm across all settings.
AI.conclusion: Fully agentic, threshold-free matrix deflation is a viable alternative to classical numerical algorithms, as demonstrated by effective performance on various datasets.

title: T3: Benchmarking Sycophancy and Skepticism in Causal Judgment
summary: We introduce T3 (Testing Trustworthy Thinking), a diagnostic benchmark designed to rigorously evaluate LLM causal judgment across Pearl's Ladder of Causality. Comprising 454 expert-curated vignettes, T3 prioritizes high-resolution failure analysis, decomposing performance into Utility (sensitivity), Safety (specificity), and Wise Refusal on underdetermined cases. By applying T3 to frontier models, we diagnose two distinct pathologies: a "Skepticism Trap" at L1 (where safety-tuned models like Claude Haiku reject 60% of valid links) and a non-monotonic Scaling Paradox at L3. In the latter, the larger GPT-5.2 underperforms GPT-4-Turbo by 55 points on ambiguous counterfactuals, driven by a collapse into paralysis (excessive hedging) rather than hallucination. Finally, we use the benchmark to validate a process-verified protocol (RCA), showing that T3 successfully captures the restoration of decisive causal judgment under structured verification.

AI.tldr: T3 is a diagnostic benchmark testing LLM causal judgment across Pearl's Ladder of Causality, revealing pathologies like Skepticism Trap and Scaling Paradox.
AI.motivation: To evaluate and diagnose how current frontier LLMs handle causal judgment systematically, as current methods lack granular failure analysis.
AI.method: Created T3 with 454 expert-curated vignettes, evaluating models on Utility, Safety, and Wise Refusal across Pearl's Ladder levels, and applied it to models like GPT-4-Turbo, GPT-5.2, and Claude Haiku.
AI.result: Identified Skepticism Trap where safety-tuned models overly reject valid links, and Scaling Paradox where larger models perform worse on ambiguous counterfactuals, without hallucination but due to excessive hedging. A process-verified protocol (RCA) restored decisive judgment.
AI.conclusion: T3 effectively diagnoses LLM causal judgment pathologies and validates interventions to improve model reliability in causal reasoning.

title: GADPN: Graph Adaptive Denoising and Perturbation Networks via Singular Value Decomposition
summary: While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) excel on graph-structured data, their performance is fundamentally limited by the quality of the observed graph, which often contains noise, missing links, or structural properties misaligned with GNNs' underlying assumptions. To address this, graph structure learning aims to infer a more optimal topology. Existing methods, however, often incur high computational costs due to complex generative models and iterative joint optimization, limiting their practical utility. In this paper, we propose GADPN, a simple yet effective graph structure learning framework that adaptively refines graph topology via low-rank denoising and generalized structural perturbation. Our approach makes two key contributions: (1) we introduce Bayesian optimization to adaptively determine the optimal denoising strength, tailoring the process to each graph's homophily level; and (2) we extend the structural perturbation method to arbitrary graphs via Singular Value Decomposition (SVD), overcoming its original limitation to symmetric structures. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GADPN achieves state-of-the-art performance while significantly improving efficiency. It shows particularly strong gains on challenging disassortative graphs, validating its ability to robustly learn enhanced graph structures across diverse network types.

AI.tldr: GADPN is an efficient graph structure learning framework that adaptively refines graph topology through low-rank denoising and generalized structural perturbation, achieving state-of-the-art performance with improved efficiency.
AI.motivation: Graph Neural Networks' performance is limited by poor-quality observed graphs containing noise, missing links, or misaligned structural properties. Existing graph structure learning methods suffer from high computational costs due to complex generative models and iterative joint optimization, limiting practical utility.
AI.method: GADPN refines graph topology via low-rank denoising and generalized structural perturbation. It uses Bayesian optimization to adaptively determine optimal denoising strength based on each graph's homophily level, and extends the structural perturbation method to arbitrary graphs using Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) to overcome original limitations to symmetric structures.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets show GADPN achieves state-of-the-art performance while significantly improving efficiency. It demonstrates particularly strong gains on challenging disassortative graphs, validating its ability to robustly learn enhanced graph structures across diverse network types.
AI.conclusion: GADPN offers a simple yet effective solution to graph structure learning that balances performance and efficiency, enabling robust topology refinement across various graph types including challenging disassortative structures.

title: VGG Induced Deep Hand Sign Language Detection
comment: Published in: Sharma, S., Ghosh, A., Subudhi, S. (2022). Hand Sign Language Detection Using Deep Learning. In: Sahoo, J.P., Tripathy, A.K., Mohanty, M., Li, KC., Nayak, A.K. (eds) Advances in Distributed Computing and Machine Learning. Lecture Notes in Networks and Systems, vol 302. Springer
summary: Hand gesture recognition is an important aspect of human-computer interaction. It forms the basis of sign language for the visually impaired people. This work proposes a novel hand gesture recognizing system for the differently-abled persons. The model uses a convolutional neural network, known as VGG-16 net, for building a trained model on a widely used image dataset by employing Python and Keras libraries. Furthermore, the result is validated by the NUS dataset, consisting of 10 classes of hand gestures, fed to the model as the validation set. Afterwards, a testing dataset of 10 classes is built by employing Google's open source Application Programming Interface (API) that captures different gestures of human hand and the efficacy is then measured by carrying out experiments. The experimental results show that by combining a transfer learning mechanism together with the image data augmentation, the VGG-16 net produced around 98% accuracy.

AI.tldr: A VGG-16 CNN-based hand gesture recognition system achieves ~98% accuracy through transfer learning and data augmentation for differently-abled persons.
AI.motivation: Hand gesture recognition is crucial for human-computer interaction and serves as the basis for sign language for visually impaired people, necessitating effective systems for differently-abled individuals.
AI.method: The system uses VGG-16 convolutional neural network implemented with Python and Keras libraries. It employs transfer learning and image data augmentation, trained on a widely used dataset and validated on the NUS dataset (10 gesture classes). A separate testing dataset is created using Google's open source API to capture various hand gestures.
AI.result: Experimental results demonstrate that combining transfer learning with image data augmentation enables the VGG-16 model to achieve approximately 98% accuracy in hand gesture recognition.
AI.conclusion: The proposed VGG-16-based system with transfer learning and data augmentation effectively recognizes hand gestures with high accuracy, making it suitable for applications benefiting differently-abled persons, particularly in sign language interpretation.

title: Incorporating Cognitive Biases into Reinforcement Learning for Financial Decision-Making
summary: Financial markets are influenced by human behavior that deviates from rationality due to cognitive biases. Traditional reinforcement learning (RL) models for financial decision-making assume rational agents, potentially overlooking the impact of psychological factors. This study integrates cognitive biases into RL frameworks for financial trading, hypothesizing that such models can exhibit human-like trading behavior and achieve better risk-adjusted returns than standard RL agents. We introduce biases, such as overconfidence and loss aversion, into reward structures and decision-making processes and evaluate their performance in simulated and real-world trading environments. Despite its inconclusive or negative results, this study provides insights into the challenges of incorporating human-like biases into RL, offering valuable lessons for developing robust financial AI systems.

AI.tldr: This paper explores integrating cognitive biases like overconfidence and loss aversion into reinforcement learning for financial trading, hypothesizing improved simulation of human-like behavior and risk-adjusted returns, but results remain inconclusive.
AI.motivation: Financial markets are affected by human behavioral deviations from rationality due to cognitive biases, and traditional RL models assume rational agents, potentially ignoring psychological factors.
AI.method: The study integrates cognitive biases into RL frameworks by introducing biases such as overconfidence and loss aversion into reward structures and decision-making processes, and evaluates performance in simulated and real-world trading environments.
AI.result: The results of the study are inconclusive or negative, indicating challenges in incorporating human-like biases into RL systems.
AI.conclusion: Despite inconclusive results, this study provides insights into the challenges of incorporating cognitive biases into RL, offering lessons for developing more robust financial AI systems.

title: Sparsity Is Necessary: Polynomial-Time Stability for Agentic LLMs in Large Action Spaces
summary: Tool-augmented LLM systems expose a control regime that learning theory has largely ignored: sequential decision-making with a massive discrete action universe (tools, APIs, documents) in which only a small, unknown subset is relevant for any fixed task distribution. We formalize this setting as Sparse Agentic Control (SAC), where policies admit block-sparse representations over M >> 1 actions and rewards depend on sparse main effects and (optionally) sparse synergies. We study ell_{1,2}-regularized policy learning through a convex surrogate and establish sharp, compressed-sensing-style results: (i) estimation and value suboptimality scale as k (log M / T)^{1/2} under a Policy-RSC condition; (ii) exact tool-support recovery holds via primal-dual witness arguments when T > k log M under incoherence and beta-min; and (iii) any dense policy class requires Omega(M) samples, explaining the instability of prompt-only controllers. We further show that under partial observability, LLMs matter only through a belief/representation error epsilon_b, yielding an additive O(epsilon_b) degradation while preserving logarithmic dependence on M. Extensions cover tuning-free, online, robust, group-sparse, and interaction-aware SAC.

AI.tldr: Tool-augmented LLMs face massive action spaces with only sparse relevance, formalized as Sparse Agentic Control (SAC). The paper shows that ℓ₁,₂-regularized policy learning achieves compressed-sensing-style guarantees with logarithmic dependence on action space size, explaining why dense policies fail and why LLMs can handle partial observability.
AI.motivation: Existing learning theory doesn't address the sequential decision-making challenge in tool-augmented LLMs, which have massive discrete action spaces (tools/APIs) where only a sparse subset is relevant for any task. Understanding how to learn effective policies in this setting is crucial for stable, efficient LLM-agent systems.
AI.method: Formalizes Sparse Agentic Control (SAC) with policies admitting block-sparse representations over M actions. Studies ℓ₁,₂-regularized policy learning through a convex surrogate. Uses Policy-RSC condition, primal-dual witness arguments, and compressed-sensing-style analysis to derive theoretical guarantees. Extends to partial observability, online, robust, group-sparse, and interaction-aware settings.
AI.result: Estimation and value suboptimality scale as k(√(log M / T)). Exact tool-support recovery requires T > k log M under incoherence and beta-min conditions. Dense policies need Ω(M) samples, explaining prompt-only instability. With partial observability, LLM belief error causes additive O(ε_b) degradation while preserving logarithmic dependence on M.
AI.conclusion: Sparse regularization enables efficient policy learning in massive action spaces with logarithmic sample complexity, providing theoretical foundation for stable tool-augmented LLM systems. The framework explains why existing approaches fail and offers principled solutions for scalable agentic control.

title: Hyperbolic Heterogeneous Graph Transformer
summary: In heterogeneous graphs, we can observe complex structures such as tree-like or hierarchical structures. Recently, the hyperbolic space has been widely adopted in many studies to effectively learn these complex structures. Although these methods have demonstrated the advantages of the hyperbolic space in learning heterogeneous graphs, most existing methods still have several challenges. They rely heavily on tangent-space operations, which often lead to mapping distortions during frequent transitions. Moreover, their message-passing architectures mainly focus on local neighborhood information, making it difficult to capture global hierarchical structures and long-range dependencies between different types of nodes. To address these limitations, we propose Hyperbolic Heterogeneous Graph Transformer (HypHGT), which effectively and efficiently learns heterogeneous graph representations entirely within the hyperbolic space. Unlike previous message-passing based hyperbolic heterogeneous GNNs, HypHGT naturally captures both local and global dependencies through transformer-based architecture. Furthermore, the proposed relation-specific hyperbolic attention mechanism in HypHGT, which operates with linear time complexity, enables efficient computation while preserving the heterogeneous information across different relation types. This design allows HypHGT to effectively capture the complex structural properties and semantic information inherent in heterogeneous graphs. We conduct comprehensive experiments to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of HypHGT, and the results demonstrate that it consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification task, with significantly reduced training time and memory usage.

AI.tldr: HypHGT is a hyperbolic heterogeneous graph transformer that learns graph representations entirely in hyperbolic space, capturing both local and global dependencies through transformer architecture with efficient relation-specific attention.
AI.motivation: Existing hyperbolic heterogeneous graph learning methods rely heavily on tangent-space operations causing mapping distortions, and focus mainly on local neighborhood information, making it difficult to capture global hierarchical structures and long-range dependencies.
AI.method: Proposes Hyperbolic Heterogeneous Graph Transformer (HypHGT) that learns entirely in hyperbolic space using transformer-based architecture. Features relation-specific hyperbolic attention mechanism with linear time complexity that preserves heterogeneous information across different relation types.
AI.result: Consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification tasks with significantly reduced training time and memory usage in comprehensive experiments.
AI.conclusion: HypHGT effectively addresses limitations of existing methods by learning entirely in hyperbolic space with transformer architecture, enabling efficient capture of complex structural properties and semantic information in heterogeneous graphs.

title: ToolACE-MCP: Generalizing History-Aware Routing from MCP Tools to the Agent Web
summary: With the rise of the Agent Web and Model Context Protocol (MCP), the agent ecosystem is evolving into an open collaborative network, exponentially increasing accessible tools. However, current architectures face severe scalability and generality bottlenecks. To address this, we propose ToolACE-MCP, a pipeline for training history-aware routers to empower precise navigation in large-scale ecosystems. By leveraging a dependency-rich candidate Graph to synthesize multi-turn trajectories, we effectively train routers with dynamic context understanding to create the plug-and-play Light Routing Agent. Experiments on the real-world benchmarks MCP-Universe and MCP-Mark demonstrate superior performance. Notably, ToolACE-MCP exhibits critical properties for the future Agent Web: it not only generalizes to multi-agent collaboration with minimal adaptation but also maintains exceptional robustness against noise and scales effectively to massive candidate spaces. These findings provide a strong empirical foundation for universal orchestration in open-ended ecosystems.

AI.tldr: ToolACE-MCP is a pipeline for training history-aware routers to enable precise navigation in large-scale agent ecosystems, addressing scalability and generality bottlenecks with dynamic context understanding and plug-and-play routing.
AI.motivation: The rise of the Agent Web and Model Context Protocol (MCP) is evolving the agent ecosystem into an open collaborative network, exponentially increasing accessible tools, but current architectures face severe scalability and generality bottlenecks.
AI.method: Propose ToolACE-MCP, a pipeline that leverages a dependency-rich candidate Graph to synthesize multi-turn trajectories for training history-aware routers, creating the plug-and-play Light Routing Agent.
AI.result: Experiments on real-world benchmarks MCP-Universe and MCP-Mark demonstrate superior performance, with ToolACE-MCP generalizing to multi-agent collaboration with minimal adaptation, maintaining robustness against noise, and scaling effectively to massive candidate spaces.
AI.conclusion: ToolACE-MCP provides a strong empirical foundation for universal orchestration in open-ended ecosystems, exhibiting critical properties for the future Agent Web.

title: LDLT L-Lipschitz Network Weight Parameterization Initialization
summary: We analyze initialization dynamics for LDLT-based $\mathcal{L}$-Lipschitz layers by deriving the exact marginal output variance when the underlying parameter matrix $W_0\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}$ is initialized with IID Gaussian entries $\mathcal{N}(0,σ^2)$. The Wishart distribution, $S=W_0W_0^\top\sim\mathcal{W}_m(n,σ^2 \boldsymbol{I}_m)$, used for computing the output marginal variance is derived in closed form using expectations of zonal polynomials via James' theorem and a Laplace-integral expansion of $(α\boldsymbol{I}_m+S)^{-1}$. We develop an Isserlis/Wick-based combinatorial expansion for $\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left[\operatorname{tr}(S^k)\right]$ and provide explicit truncated moments up to $k=10$, which yield accurate series approximations for small-to-moderate $σ^2$. Monte Carlo experiments confirm the theoretical estimates. Furthermore, empirical analysis was performed to quantify that, using current He or Kaiming initialization with scaling $1/\sqrt{n}$, the output variance is $0.41$, whereas the new parameterization with $10/ \sqrt{n}$ for $α=1$ results in an output variance of $0.9$. The findings clarify why deep $\mathcal{L}$-Lipschitz networks suffer rapid information loss at initialization and offer practical prescriptions for choosing initialization hyperparameters to mitigate this effect. However, using the Higgs boson classification dataset, a hyperparameter sweep over optimizers, initialization scale, and depth was conducted to validate the results on real-world data, showing that although the derivation ensures variance preservation, empirical results indicate He initialization still performs better.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes initialization dynamics for LDLT-based Lipschitz layers, deriving exact marginal output variance using Wishart distribution theory and combinatorial expansions, with empirical validation showing He initialization still outperforms theoretically optimal variance-preserving initialization.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to understand why deep Lipschitz networks suffer rapid information loss at initialization, and to develop practical prescriptions for choosing initialization hyperparameters to mitigate this effect by ensuring proper output variance preservation.
AI.method: The authors derive the exact marginal output variance for LDLT-based Lipschitz layers using Wishart distribution theory, James' theorem, and Laplace-integral expansions. They develop combinatorial expansions for moments of the Wishart distribution and provide explicit truncated moments up to k=10, then validate through Monte Carlo experiments and empirical analysis on Higgs boson dataset.
AI.result: The theoretical analysis shows that current He/Kaiming initialization with scaling 1/√n yields output variance of 0.41, while the new parameterization with 10/√n for α=1 achieves output variance of 0.9. However, empirical validation on real-world data surprisingly shows that He initialization still performs better despite theoretical variance preservation advantages.
AI.conclusion: While the theoretical derivation clarifies why deep Lipschitz networks suffer rapid information loss and offers improved initialization schemes for variance preservation, empirical results indicate that He initialization remains practically superior on real-world tasks, suggesting that theoretical variance preservation alone may not be sufficient for optimal performance.

title: Greedy Is Enough: Sparse Action Discovery in Agentic LLMs
summary:
Modern agentic systems operate in environments with extremely large action spaces, such as tool-augmented language models with thousands of available APIs or retrieval operations. Despite this scale, empirical evidence suggests that only a small subset of actions meaningfully influences performance in a given deployment. Motivated by this observation, we study a contextual linear reward model in which action relevance is governed by a structured sparsity assumption: only a small number of actions have nonzero effects across latent states.
  We formulate action discovery as a block-sparse recovery problem and analyze a greedy algorithm inspired by Orthogonal Matching Pursuit. Under standard assumptions on incoherence, signal strength, and action coverage, we prove that the greedy procedure exactly recovers the relevant action set with high probability, using a number of samples that scales polynomially in the sparsity level and latent dimension, and only logarithmically in the total number of actions. We further provide estimation error guarantees for refitted parameters and show that the resulting decision rule is near-optimal for new latent states.
  Complementing these results, we establish information-theoretic lower bounds demonstrating that sparsity and sufficient coverage are necessary for tractability. Together, our results identify sparse action discovery as a fundamental principle underlying large-action decision-making and provide a theoretical foundation for action pruning in agentic systems.

AI.tldr: A theoretical analysis of action discovery in large-action spaces using a greedy algorithm, proving efficient recovery of relevant actions under sparsity assumptions.
AI.motivation: Modern agentic systems have extremely large action spaces (e.g., thousands of APIs), but only a small subset of actions significantly affect performance, motivating the study of sparse action selection.
AI.method: Formulate action discovery as a block-sparse recovery problem and analyze a greedy algorithm inspired by Orthogonal Matching Pursuit, under assumptions like incoherence and signal strength.
AI.result: The greedy algorithm exactly recovers the relevant action set with high probability using samples polynomial in sparsity and logarithmic in total actions, with near-optimal decision rules for new states.
AI.conclusion: Sparse action discovery is a fundamental principle for large-action decision-making, providing a theoretical basis for action pruning in agentic systems, as supported by information-theoretic lower bounds.

title: On Evaluation of Unsupervised Feature Selection for Pattern Classification
summary: Unsupervised feature selection aims to identify a compact subset of features that captures the intrinsic structure of data without supervised label. Most existing studies evaluate the performance of methods using the single-label dataset that can be instantiated by selecting a label from multi-label data while maintaining the original features. Because the chosen label can vary arbitrarily depending on the experimental setting, the superiority among compared methods can be changed with regard to which label happens to be selected. Thus, evaluating unsupervised feature selection methods based solely on single-label accuracy is unreasonable for assessing their true discriminative ability. This study revisits this evaluation paradigm by adopting a multi-label classification framework. Experiments on 21 multi-label datasets using several representative methods demonstrate that performance rankings differ markedly from those reported under single-label settings, suggesting the possibility of multi-label evaluation settings for fair and reliable comparison of unsupervised feature selection methods.

AI.tldr: This paper critiques single-label evaluation of unsupervised feature selection and proposes using multi-label classification for fairer assessment.
AI.motivation: Existing methods rely on single-label datasets derived from multi-label data, leading to inconsistent performance rankings biased by arbitrary label selection, which unfairly evaluates discriminative ability.
AI.method: Reevaluates unsupervised feature selection via a multi-label classification framework, testing on 21 multi-label datasets to compare performance of representative methods.
AI.result: Experiments show performance rankings differ significantly from single-label settings, supporting multi-label evaluation as more reliable.
AI.conclusion: Multi-label evaluation settings provide a fairer and more trustworthy basis for comparing unsupervised feature selection methods.

title: OpenMic: A Multi-Agent-Based Stand-Up Comedy Generation System
summary: Chinese stand-up comedy generation goes beyond plain text generation, requiring culturally grounded humor, precise timing, stage-performance cues, and implicit multi-step reasoning. Moreover, commonly used Chinese humor datasets are often better suited for humor understanding and evaluation than for long-form stand-up generation, making direct supervision misaligned with the target task. To address these challenges, we present OpenMic, an end-to-end multi-agent system built on AutoGen that transforms a user-provided life topic into a 3-5 minute Chinese stand-up performance and further produces a narrated comedy video. OpenMic orchestrates multiple specialized agents in a multi-round iterative loop-planning to jointly optimize humor, timing, and performability. To mitigate the dataset-task mismatch, we augment generation with retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) for material grounding and idea expansion, and we fine-tune a dedicated JokeWriter to better internalize stand-up-specific setup-punchline structures and long-range callbacks.

AI.tldr: OpenMic is an end-to-end multi-agent system that generates Chinese stand-up comedy performances from life topics using AutoGen, focusing on humor, timing, and performability with RAG and a fine-tuned JokeWriter.
AI.motivation: Chinese stand-up comedy generation requires culturally grounded humor, precise timing, stage-performance cues, and implicit multi-step reasoning, while existing datasets are misaligned for long-form generation, necessitating a tailored approach.
AI.method: Built on AutoGen, OpenMic orchestrates multiple specialized agents in a multi-round iterative loop-planning to optimize humor, timing, and performability. It uses retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) for material grounding and idea expansion, and fine-tunes a dedicated JokeWriter for stand-up-specific structures and long-range callbacks.
AI.result: OpenMic transforms a user-provided life topic into a 3-5 minute Chinese stand-up performance and narratives a comedy video, addressing the dataset-task mismatch through multi-agent optimization and specialized components.
AI.conclusion: OpenMic effectively addresses the challenges of Chinese stand-up comedy generation by integrating multi-agent systems, RAG, and domain-specific fine-tuning, enabling the production of culturally relevant and performable comedic content.

title: A Usable GAN-Based Tool for Synthetic ECG Generation in Cardiac Amyloidosis Research
summary: Cardiac amyloidosis (CA) is a rare and underdiagnosed infiltrative cardiomyopathy, and available datasets for machine-learning models are typically small, imbalanced and heterogeneous. This paper presents a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) and a graphical command-line interface for generating realistic synthetic electrocardiogram (ECG) beats to support early diagnosis and patient stratification in CA. The tool is designed for usability, allowing clinical researchers to train class-specific generators once and then interactively produce large volumes of labelled synthetic beats that preserve the distribution of minority classes.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a GAN-based tool with a graphical interface to generate realistic synthetic ECG beats for cardiac amyloidosis diagnosis, addressing dataset limitations.
AI.motivation: Cardiac amyloidosis is underdiagnosed, and machine-learning datasets are small, imbalanced, and heterogeneous, hindering early diagnosis and patient stratification.
AI.method: The authors develop a Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) combined with a graphical command-line interface to train class-specific generators for ECG beats.
AI.result: The tool enables clinical researchers to generate large volumes of labelled synthetic ECG beats that preserve minority class distributions, supporting diagnostic tasks.
AI.conclusion: The proposed tool enhances usability for clinical researchers, facilitating early diagnosis and improved patient stratification in cardiac amyloidosis through synthetic data generation.

title: AtomMem : Learnable Dynamic Agentic Memory with Atomic Memory Operation
summary: Equipping agents with memory is essential for solving real-world long-horizon problems. However, most existing agent memory mechanisms rely on static and hand-crafted workflows. This limits the performance and generalization ability of these memory designs, which highlights the need for a more flexible, learning-based memory framework. In this paper, we propose AtomMem, which reframes memory management as a dynamic decision-making problem. We deconstruct high-level memory processes into fundamental atomic CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations, transforming the memory workflow into a learnable decision process. By combining supervised fine-tuning with reinforcement learning, AtomMem learns an autonomous, task-aligned policy to orchestrate memory behaviors tailored to specific task demands. Experimental results across 3 long-context benchmarks demonstrate that the trained AtomMem-8B consistently outperforms prior static-workflow memory methods. Further analysis of training dynamics shows that our learning-based formulation enables the agent to discover structured, task-aligned memory management strategies, highlighting a key advantage over predefined routines.

AI.tldr: AtomMem is a flexible, learning-based memory framework using atomic CRUD operations to manage memory as a dynamic decision-making problem.
AI.motivation: Existing agent memory mechanisms rely on static, hand-crafted workflows, limiting performance and generalization in long-horizon problems.
AI.method: Deconstruct memory into atomic CRUD operations, transforming workflows into a learnable process with supervised fine-tuning and reinforcement learning to train a policy.
AI.result: AtomMem-8B outperforms prior static-workflow methods across 3 long-context benchmarks, showing structured, task-aligned strategies.
AI.conclusion: Learning-based memory management is advantageous over predefined routines, enabling adaptable and efficient agent performance.

title: Demystifying the Slash Pattern in Attention: The Role of RoPE
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) often exhibit slash attention patterns, where attention scores concentrate along the $Δ$-th sub-diagonal for some offset $Δ$. These patterns play a key role in passing information across tokens. But why do they emerge? In this paper, we demystify the emergence of these Slash-Dominant Heads (SDHs) from both empirical and theoretical perspectives. First, by analyzing open-source LLMs, we find that SDHs are intrinsic to models and generalize to out-of-distribution prompts. To explain the intrinsic emergence, we analyze the queries, keys, and Rotary Position Embedding (RoPE), which jointly determine attention scores. Our empirical analysis reveals two characteristic conditions of SDHs: (1) Queries and keys are almost rank-one, and (2) RoPE is dominated by medium- and high-frequency components. Under these conditions, queries and keys are nearly identical across tokens, and interactions between medium- and high-frequency components of RoPE give rise to SDHs. Beyond empirical evidence, we theoretically show that these conditions are sufficient to ensure the emergence of SDHs by formalizing them as our modeling assumptions. Particularly, we analyze the training dynamics of a shallow Transformer equipped with RoPE under these conditions, and prove that models trained via gradient descent exhibit SDHs. The SDHs generalize to out-of-distribution prompts.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates why Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit slash attention patterns, identifying intrinsic conditions like rank-one queries/keys and RoPE frequency dominance, and proves their emergence via training dynamics.
AI.motivation: LLMs often show slash attention patterns that concentrate attention along diagonals, crucial for information flow, but the reasons for their emergence are not well understood.
AI.method: Empirical analysis of open-source LLMs and theoretical modeling, including analysis of queries, keys, and RoPE, and training dynamics of a shallow Transformer with RoPE under specified conditions.
AI.result: SDHs are intrinsic, generalize to out-of-distribution prompts, and emerge under conditions of rank-one queries/keys and medium-high frequency RoPE components, as proven theoretically.
AI.conclusion: The paper demystifies SDH emergence through empirical and theoretical insights, showing these patterns are fundamental to model training and generalize broadly.

title: Semantic Laundering in AI Agent Architectures: Why Tool Boundaries Do Not Confer Epistemic Warrant
summary: LLM-based agent architectures systematically conflate information transport mechanisms with epistemic justification mechanisms. We formalize this class of architectural failures as semantic laundering: a pattern where propositions with absent or weak warrant are accepted by the system as admissible by crossing architecturally trusted interfaces. We show that semantic laundering constitutes an architectural realization of the Gettier problem: propositions acquire high epistemic status without a connection between their justification and what makes them true. Unlike classical Gettier cases, this effect is not accidental; it is architecturally determined and systematically reproducible. The central result is the Theorem of Inevitable Self-Licensing: under standard architectural assumptions, circular epistemic justification cannot be eliminated. We introduce the Warrant Erosion Principle as the fundamental explanation for this effect and show that scaling, model improvement, and LLM-as-judge schemes are structurally incapable of eliminating a problem that exists at the type level.

AI.tldr: LLM-based agent architectures suffer from "semantic laundering" - a systematic architectural failure where propositions gain unwarranted epistemic status through trusted interfaces, creating unavoidable self-licensing problems.
AI.motivation: The paper identifies a fundamental problem in LLM-based agent architectures: they systematically conflate information transport mechanisms with epistemic justification mechanisms, creating architectural flaws that allow unwarranted claims to gain credibility.
AI.method: The authors formalize the concept of "semantic laundering" as an architectural pattern and prove the "Theorem of Inevitable Self-Licensing," showing that circular epistemic justification cannot be eliminated under standard architectural assumptions.
AI.result: The main results are: 1) semantic laundering is an architectural realization of the Gettier problem, 2) circular epistemic justification is inevitable in these systems, and 3) scaling, model improvement, and LLM-as-judge schemes cannot solve this type-level problem.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based agent architectures have a fundamental epistemic flaw - semantic laundering - that cannot be fixed by typical engineering approaches, requiring architectural redesign to properly separate information transport from epistemic justification mechanisms.

title: ORBIT: On-policy Exploration-Exploitation for Controllable Multi-Budget Reasoning
summary: Recent Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) achieve strong performance by leveraging long-form Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning, but uniformly applying overlong reasoning at inference time incurs substantial and often unnecessary computational cost. To address this, prior work explores various strategies to infer an appropriate reasoning budget from the input. However, such approaches are unreliable in the worst case, as estimating the minimal required reasoning effort is fundamentally difficult, and they implicitly fix the trade-off between reasoning cost and accuracy during training, limiting flexibility under varying deployment scenarios. Motivated by these limitations, we propose ORBIT, a controllable multi-budget reasoning framework with well-separated reasoning modes triggered by input. ORBIT employs multi-stage reinforcement learning to discover Pareto-optimal reasoning behaviors at each effort, followed by on-policy distillation to fuse these behaviors into a single unified model. Experiments show that ORBIT achieves (1) controllable reasoning behavior over multiple modes, (2) competitive reasoning density within each mode, and (3) integration of these frontier policies into a single unified student model while preserving clear mode separation and high per-mode performance.

AI.tldr: ORBIT is a controllable multi-budget reasoning framework that uses multi-stage RL and distillation to create a single model with multiple efficient reasoning modes triggered by inputs.
AI.motivation: Current LRMs use overlong Chain-of-Thought reasoning, incurring unnecessary computational costs. Prior budget-estimation approaches are unreliable and lack flexibility in adapting to different deployment scenarios.
AI.method: ORBIT uses multi-stage reinforcement learning to discover Pareto-optimal reasoning behaviors at each effort level, then employs on-policy distillation to fuse these behaviors into a single unified model with clear mode separation.
AI.result: ORBIT achieves: (1) controllable reasoning over multiple modes, (2) competitive reasoning density within each mode, and (3) successful integration into a single model while preserving mode separation and high per-mode performance.
AI.conclusion: ORBIT provides a flexible, efficient alternative to uniform overlong reasoning by enabling controllable multi-budget reasoning with optimal performance trade-offs.

title: Thematic Working Group 5 -- Artificial Intelligence (AI) literacy for teaching and learning: design and implementation
summary: TWG 5 focused on developing and implementing effective strategies for enhancing AI literacy and agency of teachers, equipping them with the knowledge and skills necessary to integrate AI into their teaching practices. Explorations covered curriculum design, professional development programs, practical classroom applications, and policy guidelines aiming to empower educators to confidently utilize AI tools and foster a deeper understanding of AI concepts among students.

AI.tldr: TW5 focuses on strategies for AI literacy and agency in teachers, enhancing their ability to integrate AI into education through curriculum, training, applications, and policies.
AI.motivation: To equip teachers with knowledge and skills for AI integration, building confidence and fostering deeper AI understanding in students, addressing gaps in educator preparedness.
AI.method: Develop and implement strategies via curriculum design, professional development programs, practical classroom applications, and policy guidelines, exploring effective approaches in educational contexts.
AI.result: Strategies and frameworks developed for enhancing teacher AI literacy and agency, likely including tools, training materials, and policy recommendations to support educators in utilizing AI.
AI.conclusion: Enhancing teacher AI literacy and agency is crucial for successful AI integration in education, with developed strategies empowering educators to confidently use AI tools and improve AI learning experiences for students.

title: Deep Exploration of Epoch-wise Double Descent in Noisy Data: Signal Separation, Large Activation, and Benign Overfitting
summary: Deep double descent is one of the key phenomena underlying the generalization capability of deep learning models. In this study, epoch-wise double descent, which is delayed generalization following overfitting, was empirically investigated by focusing on the evolution of internal structures. Fully connected neural networks of three different sizes were trained on the CIFAR-10 dataset with 30% label noise. By decomposing the loss curves into signal contributions from clean and noisy training data, the epoch-wise evolutions of internal signals were analyzed separately. Three main findings were obtained from this analysis. First, the model achieved strong re-generalization on test data even after perfectly fitting noisy training data during the double descent phase, corresponding to a "benign overfitting" state. Second, noisy data were learned after clean data, and as learning progressed, their corresponding internal activations became increasingly separated in outer layers; this enabled the model to overfit only noisy data. Third, a single, very large activation emerged in the shallow layer across all models; this phenomenon is referred as "outliers," "massive activa-tions," and "super activations" in recent large language models and evolves with re-generalization. The magnitude of large activation correlated with input patterns but not with output patterns. These empirical findings directly link the recent key phenomena of "deep double descent," "benign overfitting," and "large activation", and support the proposal of a novel scenario for understanding deep double descent.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes epoch-wise double descent in neural networks trained on noisy data, showing that models achieve re-generalization after overfitting noisy data (benign overfitting), learn noisy data after clean data with separated internal activations, and develop large "outlier" activations in shallow layers that correlate with input patterns.
AI.motivation: To empirically investigate epoch-wise double descent (delayed generalization following overfitting) by examining the evolution of internal structures in neural networks trained on noisy data, and to link key phenomena like deep double descent, benign overfitting, and large activations.
AI.method: Trained fully connected neural networks of three different sizes on CIFAR-10 dataset with 30% label noise. Decomposed loss curves into signal contributions from clean and noisy training data to analyze epoch-wise evolutions of internal signals separately.
AI.result: Three main findings: 1) Models achieved strong re-generalization on test data even after perfectly fitting noisy training data (benign overfitting), 2) Noisy data were learned after clean data with their internal activations becoming increasingly separated in outer layers, 3) Large "outlier" activations emerged in shallow layers across all models, correlating with input patterns but not output patterns.
AI.conclusion: The empirical findings directly link deep double descent, benign overfitting, and large activation phenomena, supporting a novel scenario for understanding deep double descent where models can overfit noisy data while maintaining generalization capability through structural changes in internal activations.

title: A Qualitative Model to Reason about Object Rotations (QOR) applied to solve the Cube Comparison Test (CCT)
summary: This paper presents a Qualitative model for Reasoning about Object Rotations (QOR) which is applied to solve the Cube Comparison Test (CCT) by Ekstrom et al. (1976). A conceptual neighborhood graph relating the Rotation movement to the Location change and the Orientation change (CNGRLO) of the features on the cube sides has been built and it produces composition tables to calculate inferences for reasoning about rotations.

AI.tldr: The paper presents QOR, a qualitative model for reasoning about object rotations, specifically applied to solve the Cube Comparison Test by building a conceptual neighborhood graph relating rotation to location and orientation changes.
AI.motivation: To develop a qualitative reasoning approach for solving spatial reasoning problems involving object rotations, specifically targeting the Cube Comparison Test which requires mental rotation and comparison of 3D objects.
AI.method: Built a conceptual neighborhood graph (CNGRLO) that relates rotation movement to location and orientation changes of cube features, and used this to produce composition tables for calculating inferences about rotations.
AI.result: The QOR model successfully solves the Cube Comparison Test by providing a systematic qualitative reasoning framework for understanding and predicting how object rotations affect feature locations and orientations.
AI.conclusion: The qualitative model for reasoning about object rotations provides an effective approach to spatial reasoning problems, demonstrating that conceptual neighborhood graphs and composition tables can successfully handle complex rotation-based inference tasks.

title: Automated Machine Learning in Radiomics: A Comparative Evaluation of Performance, Efficiency and Accessibility
comment: 27 pages, 4 figures, 3 tables, code available, see https://github.com/joselznom/AutoML-Comparison-in-Radiomics
summary: Automated machine learning (AutoML) frameworks can lower technical barriers for predictive and prognostic model development in radiomics by enabling researchers without programming expertise to build models. However, their effectiveness in addressing radiomics-specific challenges remains unclear. This study evaluates the performance, efficiency, and accessibility of general-purpose and radiomics-specific AutoML frameworks on diverse radiomics classification tasks, thereby highlighting development needs for radiomics. Ten public/private radiomics datasets with varied imaging modalities (CT/MRI), sizes, anatomies and endpoints were used. Six general-purpose and five radiomics-specific frameworks were tested with predefined parameters using standardized cross-validation. Evaluation metrics included AUC, runtime, together with qualitative aspects related to software status, accessibility, and interpretability. Simplatab, a radiomics-specific tool with a no-code interface, achieved the highest average test AUC (81.81%) with a moderate runtime (~1 hour). LightAutoML, a general-purpose framework, showed the fastest execution with competitive performance (78.74% mean AUC in six minutes). Most radiomics-specific frameworks were excluded from the performance analysis due to obsolescence, extensive programming requirements, or computational inefficiency. Conversely, general-purpose frameworks demonstrated higher accessibility and ease of implementation. Simplatab provides an effective balance of performance, efficiency, and accessibility for radiomics classification problems. However, significant gaps remain, including the lack of accessible survival analysis support and the limited integration of feature reproducibility and harmonization within current AutoML frameworks. Future research should focus on adapting AutoML solutions to better address these radiomics-specific challenges.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates AutoML frameworks for radiomics, finding Simplatab top for performance-efficiency-accessibility balance, with gaps in survival analysis and feature handling.
AI.motivation: AutoML frameworks can help non-experts in radiomics, but their effectiveness for radiomics-specific challenges is unclear, requiring evaluation.
AI.method: Used 10 radiomics datasets with CT/MRI, tested 6 general-purpose and 5 radiomics-specific AutoML frameworks via standardized cross-validation, measuring AUC, runtime, and qualitative aspects.
AI.result: Simplatab achieved highest test AUC (81.81%) with moderate runtime; LightAutoML was fastest with competitive AUC; most radiomics-specific tools excluded due to issues; general-purpose tools more accessible.
AI.conclusion: Simplatab effectively balances performance, efficiency, and accessibility for radiomics classification, but gaps like survival analysis support need addressing; future work should adapt AutoML to radiomics-specific challenges.

title: Deconstructing Pre-training: Knowledge Attribution Analysis in MoE and Dense Models
summary: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures decouple model capacity from per-token computation, enabling scaling beyond the computational limits imposed by dense scaling laws. Yet how MoE architectures shape knowledge acquisition during pre-training, and how this process differs from dense architectures, remains unknown. To address this issue, we introduce Gated-LPI (Log-Probability Increase), a neuron-level attribution metric that decomposes log-probability increase across neurons. We present a time-resolved comparison of knowledge acquisition dynamics in MoE and dense architectures, tracking checkpoints over 1.2M training steps (~ 5.0T tokens) and 600K training steps (~ 2.5T tokens), respectively. Our experiments uncover three patterns: (1) Low-entropy backbone. The top approximately 1% of MoE neurons capture over 45% of positive updates, forming a high-utility core, which is absent in the dense baseline. (2) Early consolidation. The MoE model locks into a stable importance profile within < 100K steps, whereas the dense model remains volatile throughout training. (3) Functional robustness. Masking the ten most important MoE attention heads reduces relational HIT@10 by < 10%, compared with > 50% for the dense model, showing that sparsity fosters distributed -- rather than brittle -- knowledge storage. These patterns collectively demonstrate that sparsity fosters an intrinsically stable and distributed computational backbone from early in training, helping bridge the gap between sparse architectures and training-time interpretability.

AI.tldr: MoE architectures develop a stable, distributed computational backbone with a small core of high-utility neurons that emerges early and remains robust to masking, unlike dense models which show volatile, brittle knowledge storage throughout training.
AI.motivation: To understand how MoE architectures differ from dense architectures in knowledge acquisition during pre-training, and to bridge the gap between sparse architectures and training-time interpretability.
AI.method: Introduces Gated-LPI (Log-Probability Increase), a neuron-level attribution metric that decomposes log-probability increases across neurons. Conducts time-resolved comparison tracking checkpoints over extensive training steps (1.2M for MoE, 600K for dense).
AI.result: Three key patterns: (1) Low-entropy backbone with top 1% of MoE neurons capturing over 45% of positive updates, (2) Early consolidation with MoE stabilizing within <100K steps vs dense volatility, (3) Functional robustness with MoE heads showing <10% performance drop when masked vs >50% for dense.
AI.conclusion: Sparsity in MoE architectures fosters an intrinsically stable and distributed computational backbone from early in training, enabling robust knowledge storage and helping bridge interpretability gaps.

title: Decodable but not structured: linear probing enables Underwater Acoustic Target Recognition with pretrained audio embeddings
summary: Increasing levels of anthropogenic noise from ships contribute significantly to underwater sound pollution, posing risks to marine ecosystems. This makes monitoring crucial to understand and quantify the impact of the ship radiated noise. Passive Acoustic Monitoring (PAM) systems are widely deployed for this purpose, generating years of underwater recordings across diverse soundscapes. Manual analysis of such large-scale data is impractical, motivating the need for automated approaches based on machine learning. Recent advances in automatic Underwater Acoustic Target Recognition (UATR) have largely relied on supervised learning, which is constrained by the scarcity of labeled data. Transfer Learning (TL) offers a promising alternative to mitigate this limitation. In this work, we conduct the first empirical comparative study of transfer learning for UATR, evaluating multiple pretrained audio models originating from diverse audio domains. The pretrained model weights are frozen, and the resulting embeddings are analyzed through classification, clustering, and similarity-based evaluations. The analysis shows that the geometrical structure of the embedding space is largely dominated by recording-specific characteristics. However, a simple linear probe can effectively suppress this recording-specific information and isolate ship-type features from these embeddings. As a result, linear probing enables effective automatic UATR using pretrained audio models at low computational cost, significantly reducing the need for a large amounts of high-quality labeled ship recordings.

AI.tldr: This paper performs the first empirical comparative study of transfer learning for Underwater Acoustic Target Recognition (UATR), evaluating pretrained audio models to automate ship noise monitoring with less labeled data.
AI.motivation: Increasing anthropogenic ship noise poses risks to marine ecosystems, requiring monitoring via Passive Acoustic Monitoring (PAM) systems that generate large-scale underwater recordings. Manual analysis is impractical, and supervised learning for automatic UATR is limited by scarce labeled data.
AI.method: Conduct transfer learning for UATR by evaluating multiple pretrained audio models from diverse audio domains. Pretrained model weights are frozen, and embeddings are analyzed using classification, clustering, and similarity-based evaluations.
AI.result: The embedding space is largely dominated by recording-specific characteristics. However, a simple linear probe can suppress this information and isolate ship-type features, enabling effective automatic UATR with low computational cost.
AI.conclusion: Linear probing on pretrained audio models allows effective automated UATR with minimal labeled ship recordings, offering a scalable approach to monitor anthropogenic noise impacts on marine ecosystems.

title: Creativity in AI as Emergence from Domain-Limited Generative Models
summary: Creativity in artificial intelligence is most often addressed through evaluative frameworks that aim to measure novelty, diversity, or usefulness in generated outputs. While such approaches have provided valuable insights into the behavior of modern generative models, they largely treat creativity as a property to be assessed rather than as a phenomenon to be explicitly modeled. In parallel, recent advances in large-scale generative systems, particularly multimodal architectures, have demonstrated increasingly sophisticated forms of pattern recombination, raising questions about the nature and limits of machine creativity. This paper proposes a generative perspective on creativity in AI, framing it as an emergent property of domain-limited generative models embedded within bounded informational environments. Rather than introducing new evaluative criteria, we focus on the structural and contextual conditions under which creative behaviors arise. We introduce a conceptual decomposition of creativity into four interacting components-pattern-based generation, induced world models, contextual grounding, and arbitrarity, and examine how these components manifest in multimodal generative systems. By grounding creativity in the interaction between generative dynamics and domain-specific representations, this work aims to provide a technical framework for studying creativity as an emergent phenomenon in AI systems, rather than as a post hoc evaluative label.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a generative perspective on AI creativity as an emergent property of domain-limited models in bounded informational environments, decomposing creativity into four components rather than focusing on evaluative criteria.
AI.motivation: Current AI creativity research focuses on evaluative frameworks measuring novelty/diversity/usefulness, treating creativity as a property to assess rather than a phenomenon to model. Advances in multimodal generative systems show sophisticated pattern recombination, raising questions about the nature and limits of machine creativity.
AI.method: Proposes a generative perspective framing creativity as emergent from domain-limited models in bounded informational environments. Introduces conceptual decomposition of creativity into four components: pattern-based generation, induced world models, contextual grounding, and arbitrarity. Examines how these manifest in multimodal generative systems.
AI.result: Provides a technical framework for studying creativity as an emergent phenomenon in AI systems rather than as a post hoc evaluative label. Grounds creativity in the interaction between generative dynamics and domain-specific representations.
